questions.question: Look at the section beginning with ‘MOST NINE-YEAR-OLD BOYS PLAY...’ What impressions of the exhibit is this section trying to give?

questions.question: Explain why the image of a scroll is effective in this advertisement.

questions.subject: English
questions.paper: 2016 Sec 4 Express English SA2 Commonwealth Secondary School
questions.question: Look at the section that begins with ‘To say he was born to rule...’ Why is there a switch from past tense to present tense?

questions.subject: English
questions.paper: 2016 Sec 4 Express English SA2 Commonwealth Secondary School
questions.question: What new opportunity is the writer suggesting in Paragraph 2?

questions.subject: English
questions.paper: 2016 Sec 4 Express English SA2 Commonwealth Secondary School
questions.question: In paragraph 2, the writer writes that ‘Claude buckles the meat into his wife’s matching vinyl suitcases and carries them himself by train to Paris.’ What is unusual about the description in italics?

questions.subject: English
questions.paper: 2016 Sec 4 Express English SA2 Commonwealth Secondary School
questions.question: In paragraph 2, the writer writes that ‘Claude buckles the meat into his wife’s matching vinyl suitcases and carries them himself by train to Paris.’Why do you think he packed the meat in this way?

questions.subject: English
questions.paper: 2016 Sec 4 Express English SA2 Commonwealth Secondary School
questions.question: The writer writes that ‘It takes a mind like Claude’s to navigate the complexities of the business (lines 9-10).’ What ‘complexities’ is the writer referring to? Pick a phrase from this paragraph that supports your answer.

questions.subject: English
questions.paper: 2016 Sec 4 Express English SA2 Commonwealth Secondary School
questions.question: The writer writes that ‘It takes a mind like Claude’s to navigate the complexities of the business (lines 9-10).’ What characteristic is the writer suggesting about Claude with this line?

questions.subject: English
questions.paper: 2016 Sec 4 Express English SA2 Commonwealth Secondary School
questions.question: (i) In paragraph 3, the writer says ‘October is here, and bright cold winds ought to pour off the ocean; leaves ought to tumble down the alleys. Saint-Malo roasts.’ Explain how the writer creates a contrast between these two sentences. (ii) What is the effect of this contrast?

questions.subject: English
questions.paper: 2016 Sec 4 Express English SA2 Commonwealth Secondary School
questions.question: Why does the writer use one sentence to compose the whole of paragraph 4?

questions.subject: English
questions.paper: 2016 Sec 4 Express English SA2 Commonwealth Secondary School
questions.question: Paying attention to the italicised descriptions, how does the writer portray the German soldiers in paragraph 5? (i) ‘carry their weapons barrel-down, slinging them over their shoulders like clarinets’ (ii) ‘seemed touched underneath their helmets with a beneficent gold’

questions.subject: English
questions.paper: 2016 Sec 4 Express English SA2 Commonwealth Secondary School
questions.question: Claude observes the German soldiers in paragraph 6. What does his thought ‘Something his own country has lacked’ suggest about his attitude towards his country?

questions.subject: English
questions.paper: 2016 Sec 4 Express English SA2 Commonwealth Secondary School
questions.question: Which word in paragraph 7 suggests Claude’s interest towards his neighbour?

questions.subject: English
questions.paper: 2016 Sec 4 Express English SA2 Commonwealth Secondary School
questions.question: Why is the repetition of ‘This’ in paragraph 10 particularly effective?

questions.subject: English
questions.paper: 2016 Sec 4 Express English SA2 Commonwealth Secondary School
questions.question: The structure of the text reflects the main stages in the narrative. Complete the flow chart by choosing the appropriate phrase from the box to summarise the main focus in the paragraphs given below. (i) Paragraphs 1-2 (ii) Paragraph 3 (iii) Paragraph 6 (iv) Paragraph 8

questions.subject: English
questions.paper: 2016 Sec 4 Express English SA2 Commonwealth Secondary School
questions.question: The writer describes modern men as ‘soulless appendages to their desktop computers’ (lines 4-5). Write down a phrase from the same paragraph that reflects a similar meaning.

questions.subject: English
questions.paper: 2016 Sec 4 Express English SA2 Commonwealth Secondary School
questions.question: From paragraph 2, what is the effect of the ‘much hyped advances in technology’ on us? Answer in your own words.

questions.subject: English
questions.paper: 2016 Sec 4 Express English SA2 Commonwealth Secondary School
questions.question: Anne: Bond and his villains certainly work in contrasting environments! (a) Give evidence from paragraph 4 to support Anne’s view.

questions.subject: English
questions.paper: 2016 Sec 4 Express English SA2 Commonwealth Secondary School
questions.question: Anne: Bond and his villains certainly work in contrasting environments! Ben: Well, it’s more than the environment. He’s trying to contrast Bond’s and his villains’ differing natures. (b) Explain with reference to paragraph 4 why Ben feels as he does.

questions.subject: English
questions.paper: 2016 Sec 4 Express English SA2 Commonwealth Secondary School
questions.question: From paragraph 6, give two examples of how the Bond story is a ‘twentieth-century folk epic’ (line 36).

questions.subject: English
questions.paper: 2016 Sec 4 Express English SA2 Commonwealth Secondary School
questions.question: Why is the comparison of Bond to ‘spiritual fuel’ (line 61) effective?

questions.subject: English
questions.paper: 2016 Sec 4 Express English SA2 Commonwealth Secondary School
questions.question: Using your own words as far as possible, summarise what makes Bond a hero for audiences today. Use only the material from paragraphs 1-3, 5 and 8 of Text 3. Your summary must be in continuous writing (not note form). It must not be longer than 80 words, not counting the words given to help you begin.
